page.title: 01North & East of Etal Village
page.content: This is a rural, agricultural area, the largest centre of population being Etal Village, with approximately fifty inhabitants. It is an unspoilt area which is just beginning to become more popular with tourists. The River Till, a tributary of the Tweed, runs through the South west corner of the block. Etal has the ruins of a 13th C castle, and, unusually for Northumberland, has three thatched houses (including the pub). The farmland is mainly grain producing, although there is some sheep farming & a limited number of cattle. Part of the area is a managed estate owned by Lord Joicey of Etal Manor, which raises game birds for shooting. Most residents work locally or are retired. A few people in recent years have moved into the area to set up small businesses & craft workshops in buildings made vacant by the
